news_summary: Today's environmental news highlights the vital role of healthy wildlife in enhancing forest carbon storage, practical ways to minimize coffee pod waste, and creative eco-friendly activities that promote sustainability.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité environnementale d'aujourd'hui met en lumière le rôle vital d'une faune et d'une flore sauvages en bonne santé dans l'amélioration du stockage du carbone dans les forêts, les moyens pratiques de réduire le gaspillage des dosettes de café et les activités créatives respectueuses de l'environnement qui favorisent la durabilité.
news_summary_es: Las noticias medioambientales de hoy destacan el papel vital de una fauna sana en la mejora del almacenamiento de carbono en los bosques, formas prácticas de minimizar los residuos de las cápsulas de café y actividades ecológicas creativas que promueven la sostenibilidad.

articles.title: Hard paths: how courage differs from bravery in science
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 28 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01861-y‘If it’s easy, someone else will do it.’ Leah Ellis, chief executive of Sublime Systems, explains the challenge and appeal of slashing carbon emissions from cement production.
articles.content:
Leah Ellis co-founded Sublime Systems in 2020. Credit: Bob O'Connor

Sublime Systems, based in Somerville, Massachusetts, seeks to produce cement without using combustion, to cut down on energy use and pollution.

Leah Ellis, its chief executive and co-founder, talks about how to solve problems by working backwards, why choosing the harder career path often appeals and how courage differs from bravery in science entrepreneurship.

What pivotal moments have you had in your entrepreneurial career?

In 2018, I was awarded a Banting Postdoctoral Fellowship by the Canadian Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council. It enabled me to work with materials scientist and engineer Yet-Ming Chiang at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Cambridge. When we met, Yet-Ming had already spun off six start-up companies from his research, and five have gone on to become unicorns (privately listed companies valued at more than US$1 billion). I liked his approach of developing a technology and analysing its economic viability right from its initial stages. We co-founded Sublime Systems in 2020.

Another, earlier, influence was during my undergraduate and higher degrees at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Canada. I fell into the orbit of lithium-ion-battery pioneer Jeff Dahn, who was my PhD supervisor and mentor. During my PhD, we were contracted by electric-vehicle manufacturer Tesla and the technology company 3M to do research on lithium-ion batteries and to expand their intellectual property (IP) portfolio. Jeff’s deal with the university allowed him to be funded and to work directly with industry. We got their funding; they got our IP.

It was the coolest PhD ever. We were focused on developing real-world innovations for actual companies. Few scientists get the opportunity to work so closely with industry during graduate school. I wish more universities allowed this.

How did Sublime Systems come about?

Yet-Ming has an audacious and creative way of inventing. His idea, and the mission for Sublime, was to produce cement without using combustion, through electrochemical processes. As a freshly minted PhD holder, I would never have had the vision and audacity to work backwards from such a big thesis.

Can you tell us some more about the technology?

Globally, the electricity and heating sector contributes an estimated 40% to global carbon dioxide emissions. The goal is to reduce these to zero, using existing technologies including solar panels, wind turbines, nuclear, hydroelectricity and storage.

Cement production creates around 8% of CO 2 emissions: half from the decomposition of limestone, and half from combustion needed to heat the kiln to 1,450 ºC. Globally, we use about 4 billion tonnes of cement a year, and each tonne of portland cement, the most common type used today, emits around 1 tonne of CO 2 .

Most of the CO 2 footprint comes from the mineral emissions from the carbonate, as well as the fossil-fuel emissions needed to heat that limestone up to very high temperatures. Our process breaks down minerals without heat, using water splitting (into its constituents, hydrogen and oxygen). We call this process an ambient-temperature refinery for rocks. When splitting is done at a near-neutral pH, you can create a pH gradient — acid at one electrode and base at the other. We use that pH gradient to dissolve metals out of rocks, and then sequentially precipitate those metals. We can take almost any calcium-bearing mineral and dissolve and separate it into its constituent pure minerals, avoiding high temperatures. We can also avoid the mineral emissions from limestone, because we can use minerals such as silicates and others that aren’t bound with CO 2 .

Sublime Systems makes cement without using conventional combustion techniques.Credit: Mikhail Glabets

The hardened state of the concrete is the same as portland and Roman cement (the type developed in the eighteenth century, which resembles mortars used by the Romans), with similar strength and durability, engineered to have the same properties in the field but without the emissions.

What is your underlying philosophy as a science entrepreneur?

‘If it’s easy, someone else will do it.’

I’m driven by US president John F. Kennedy’s 1962 Moonshot speech at Rice University in Houston, Texas, when he said: “We choose to go to the Moon. We choose to go to the Moon in this decade and do the other things, not because they are easy, but because they are hard.”

At university, I wanted to really get my money’s worth by doing something hard, by learning something I couldn’t have figured out on my own or through a book. I majored in chemistry. It was the discipline that felt the hardest.

I worked my way through college in my home town of Halifax, making minimum wage as a cashier and shelf-stocker at an organic grocery store. And in 2014, between my master’s and PhD, I did the Tour d’Afrique, which is a 12,000-kilometre trip from Cairo to Cape Town by bicycle, sleeping on the ground every night — it’s something I would recommend to both best friends and worst enemies!

At Sublime, we are tackling a hard problem — pun intended — because the cement industry is one of the most difficult to approach, owing to its sheer scale. By mass, cement is one of the cheapest materials, at around $150 per tonne, so you need massive economies of scale — more than one million tonnes per year per plant — to make a healthy profit. The industry is very consolidated: a handful of big multinational companies dominates the market. So to come in as a fledgling start-up to disrupt this is ambitious.

How are you scaling up and expanding the team at Sublime?

You start with the basics. What does this technology need to get to the next level?

So, first it was scientists, to provide proof of concept. Next, we needed engineers to build a pilot plant in Somerville, just 15 minutes from MIT. Then you need business-development and operations people. We’re now at the size where you really need experienced executives who’ve run large, publicly traded companies before.

Our technology doesn’t fit squarely into cement or electrochemistry, so the team (now almost 100 full-time equivalents) is a mix of mechanical engineers, chemists, materials scientists and civil engineers. Some people know the same discipline from different angles. This contrasts with the more siloed ways of working at a university.

It has always been about finding the resources needed at the right time for the scale and maturity of the business. Being in Boston around such academic excellence (it’s home to institutions including MIT, Harvard University, Boston University, Tufts and Northeastern, for example) really lent itself to that.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the challenge and appeal of reducing carbon emissions from cement production, which is a significant environmental issue. It focuses on scientific and technological efforts to address climate change, which is hopeful and inspiring for a wide audience.
articles.personality_title: How courage is driving cleaner cement innovation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Cement production is a major source of carbon emissions, making it a tough problem for climate change. Traditional methods use combustion, which burns fuel and releases a lot of pollution.

**What happened**
Leah Ellis, CEO of Sublime Systems, is leading a bold effort to make cement without burning fuel. Founded in 2020 in Massachusetts, her company is developing technology that cuts energy use and pollution by avoiding combustion altogether.

**Impact**
This new approach could drastically reduce carbon emissions from cement, a key step toward cleaner construction worldwide. Leah’s focus on solving hard problems by working backward and choosing the difficult path shows how courage—not just bravery—guides real innovation.

**What's next step**
Sublime Systems plans to keep refining their technology and scale it up, proving that tough challenges in science can be overcome with smart, courageous entrepreneurship.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Tackling climate change means choosing hard paths with courage—like making cement without combustion—to create a cleaner future.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment le courage stimule l'innovation dans le ciment propre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La production de ciment est une source importante d'émissions de carbone, un problème majeur pour le climat. Les méthodes traditionnelles utilisent la combustion, qui brûle du carburant et libère beaucoup de pollution.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Leah Ellis, PDG de Sublime Systems, mène un effort audacieux pour fabriquer du ciment sans brûler de combustible. Fondée en 2020 dans le Massachusetts, son entreprise développe une technologie qui réduit la consommation d'énergie et la pollution en évitant complètement la combustion.

**Impact**
Cette nouvelle méthode pourrait fortement réduire les émissions de carbone liées au ciment, un pas clé vers une construction plus propre dans le monde. L'approche de Leah, qui consiste à résoudre les problèmes complexes en partant de la fin et à choisir la voie difficile, montre que le courage—et pas seulement la bravoure—guide la vraie innovation.

**Prochaine étape**
Sublime Systems prévoit de continuer à améliorer sa technologie et à la déployer à grande échelle, prouvant que les défis scientifiques difficiles peuvent être relevés grâce à un entrepreneuriat intelligent et courageux.

**Message en une phrase**
Lutter contre le changement climatique signifie choisir des chemins difficiles avec courage—comme fabriquer du ciment sans combustion—pour créer un avenir plus propre.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo el coraje impulsa la innovación en cemento más limpio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La producción de cemento es una gran fuente de emisiones de carbono, un problema difícil para el cambio climático. Los métodos tradicionales usan combustión, que quema combustible y libera mucha contaminación.

**Qué pasó**
Leah Ellis, directora ejecutiva de Sublime Systems, lidera un esfuerzo valiente para fabricar cemento sin quemar combustible. Fundada en 2020 en Massachusetts, su empresa desarrolla tecnología que reduce el uso de energía y la contaminación al evitar la combustión por completo.

**Impacto**
Este nuevo enfoque podría reducir drásticamente las emisiones de carbono del cemento, un paso clave hacia construcciones más limpias en todo el mundo. La forma de Leah de resolver problemas difíciles trabajando hacia atrás y eligiendo el camino difícil muestra cómo el coraje—no solo la valentía—guía la verdadera innovación.

**Próximo paso**
Sublime Systems planea seguir mejorando su tecnología y ampliarla, demostrando que los retos científicos difíciles pueden superarse con un emprendimiento inteligente y valiente.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Enfrentar el cambio climático significa elegir caminos difíciles con coraje—como hacer cemento sin combustión—para crear un futuro más limpio.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a glowing, stylized electrochemical cell gently splitting limestone rocks into pure mineral components, surrounded by softly flowing streams of clean water and light, set against a calm, softly colored industrial landscape with abstract silhouettes of scientists and engineers collaborating, symbolizing innovative, sustainable cement production without combustion.

articles.title: Forests with robust animal populations store four times as much carbon
articles.summary: An analysis of thousands of forest plots reveals an underappreciated link between animal biodiversity and carbon storage
articles.content:
An analysis of thousands of forest plots reveals an underappreciated link between animal biodiversity and carbon storage

Animals like capuchin monkeys help spread seeds in tropical forests Carlos Grillo/Getty Images/iStockphoto

Tropical forests populated with a diversity of seed-dispersing animals can accumulate carbon up to four times as fast as fragmented forests where these animals are absent or their movement is restricted.

“This shows a linkage between animal biodiversity loss and a process that exacerbates climate change,” says Evan Fricke at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. “We’re losing the regrowth potential of tropical forests.”

Advertisement

Animals contain just a tiny fraction of the carbon stored in the environments where they live. But there is increasing recognition their activities can have outsized impacts on their ecosystems’ carbon. One important contribution comes from animals like monkeys, birds and rodents, whose behaviour disperses a great diversity of seeds across a wide area.

Still, “it’s been really hard to translate that to the long-scale processes like the carbon recovery of entire landscapes”, says Fricke.

Fricke and his colleagues analysed more than 3000 plots in tropical forests where trees were growing back – and accumulating carbon – after a disturbance. They then estimated the amount of disruption to the movement and diversity of seed-dispersing animals in each plot. The estimates relied on factors like the amount of forest fragmentation and data from tracked animals.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

They found more disruption to the movement of seed dispersers was clearly linked with a lower rate of carbon accumulation. Forests that had the least disruption to their animals’ habits grew four times as fast as the most disrupted ones.

On average, disruptions to seed-dispersing animals’ diversity and movement reduced the amount of carbon the plots could accumulate by half. This means the disruptions had an even larger negative effect than other factors limiting tree regrowth, such as fires or livestock grazing.

Conversely, forests with the least disruption accumulated carbon even faster than monoculture tree plantations. “Natural growth amplified by animals offers a low cost and biodiversity-positive restoration strategy,” says Fricke.

Previously, ecological models suggested seed dispersers could have a substantial effect on carbon. But this study “improves our understanding of how important these animals could be”, says Oswald Schmitz at Yale University. “And it shows that they’re going to be important.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a scientific finding that links robust animal populations in forests to significantly higher carbon storage, emphasizing the importance of biodiversity for climate change mitigation. This represents environmental progress and conservation success, which is positive and hopeful news for the planet.
articles.personality_title: Forests rich in wildlife store four times more carbon
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Forests play a big role in fighting climate change by storing carbon, which helps keep our air clean. But not all forests store carbon equally. Scientists have been curious about how animals living in these forests might affect this carbon storage.

**What happened**
Researchers studied thousands of forest areas and found that forests with lots of animals, especially those that spread seeds like monkeys, store up to four times more carbon than forests where animals are few or can’t move freely. Animals help plants grow by spreading seeds far and wide, which leads to bigger, healthier trees that hold more carbon.

**Impact**
This discovery shows that protecting wildlife isn’t just good for animals—it’s great for our planet’s climate too. Healthy animal populations help forests grow stronger and capture more carbon, which slows down global warming.

**What's next step**
Efforts to conserve forests should also focus on protecting the animals that live there. This means creating safe habitats and corridors so animals can move freely, helping nature do its job better in absorbing carbon.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Keeping forests full of wildlife is a powerful way to store more carbon and fight climate change.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les forêts riches en faune stockent quatre fois plus de carbone
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les forêts jouent un grand rôle dans la lutte contre le changement climatique en stockant le carbone, ce qui aide à garder notre air propre. Mais toutes les forêts ne stockent pas le carbone de la même façon. Les scientifiques se sont intéressés à l’impact des animaux vivant dans ces forêts.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs ont étudié des milliers de zones forestières et ont découvert que les forêts avec beaucoup d’animaux, notamment ceux qui dispersent les graines comme les singes capucins, stockent jusqu’à quatre fois plus de carbone que les forêts où les animaux sont rares ou ne peuvent pas se déplacer librement. Les animaux aident les plantes à pousser en dispersant les graines sur de grandes distances, ce qui donne des arbres plus grands et en meilleure santé, capables de retenir plus de carbone.

**Impact**
Cette découverte montre que protéger la faune n’est pas seulement bénéfique pour les animaux, c’est aussi excellent pour le climat de notre planète. Des populations animales en bonne santé aident les forêts à devenir plus fortes et à capturer plus de carbone, ralentissant ainsi le réchauffement climatique.

**Prochaine étape**
Les efforts pour conserver les forêts devraient aussi viser à protéger les animaux qui y vivent. Cela signifie créer des habitats sûrs et des corridors pour que les animaux puissent se déplacer librement, aidant ainsi la nature à mieux absorber le carbone.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Maintenir des forêts pleines de vie sauvage est un moyen puissant de stocker plus de carbone et de lutter contre le changement climatique.
articles.personality_title_es: Los bosques con mucha vida animal almacenan cuatro veces más carbono
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los bosques son muy importantes para combatir el cambio climático porque almacenan carbono, lo que ayuda a mantener limpio nuestro aire. Pero no todos los bosques almacenan carbono de la misma forma. Los científicos querían saber cómo afectan los animales que viven allí.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores estudiaron miles de áreas forestales y encontraron que los bosques con muchos animales, especialmente los que esparcen semillas como los monos capuchinos, almacenan hasta cuatro veces más carbono que los bosques donde hay pocos animales o estos no pueden moverse libremente. Los animales ayudan a que crezcan plantas al dispersar semillas lejos, lo que genera árboles más grandes y saludables que retienen más carbono.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo muestra que proteger a los animales no solo es bueno para ellos, sino también para el clima de nuestro planeta. Las poblaciones saludables de animales ayudan a que los bosques crezcan más fuertes y capturen más carbono, lo que frena el calentamiento global.

**Próximo paso**
Los esfuerzos para conservar los bosques también deben enfocarse en proteger a los animales que viven allí. Esto implica crear hábitats seguros y corredores para que los animales puedan moverse libremente, ayudando a la naturaleza a absorber mejor el carbono.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Mantener los bosques llenos de vida animal es una forma poderosa de almacenar más carbono y combatir el cambio climático.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a thriving tropical forest scene featuring lively capuchin monkeys and colorful birds actively spreading seeds among diverse young trees, with vibrant greenery symbolizing rapid carbon growth and interconnected animal life fostering a flourishing ecosystem.

articles.title: How to Reduce the Impact of Your Coffee Pod Consumption
articles.summary:
More than 20 billion coffee pods are disposed of globally each year. In fact, 39,000...
The post How to Reduce the Impact of Your Coffee Pod Consumption appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
More than 20 billion coffee pods are disposed of globally each year. In fact, 39,000 pods are produced every minute. These conveniences produce waste on a massive scale and represent a sustainability concern for consumers and policymakers across the nation.

Coffee pods are made from a variety of materials, each with a different environmental impact.

Plastic pods are technically recyclable, but often end up in landfills due to contamination and their small size, which most recycling systems struggle to sort from other materials.

Aluminum pods are more valuable but difficult to recycle due to contamination, and only specialized programs can handle them.

Compostable pods made from PLA need industrial composting to break down properly. In landfills, PLA can release methane, a potent greenhouse gas with 28 times more warming potential than CO₂.

Proper recycling or composting a coffee pod can cut 2g to 5g CO₂ per pod, and if you consume a lot of coffee that can add up significantly over time. However, improper disposal contributes to over 400 million pounds of pod waste annually in the U.S.

Carbon Emissions in Coffee Pod Production

Coffee pods and your morning brew produce environmental impacts at every step of the production and coffee-making process:

Coffee Farming is the biggest source of emissions. Producing 1 kg of Arabica coffee emits approximately 15 kg of CO₂ due to land and water use, packaging, transportation, and processing. [MR1] [FN2] [FN3]

Coffee Use : A coffee pod typically contains about 5.7g of coffee, slightly less than the 7g used in a standard cup of filter coffee, which helps reduce the environmental impact of raw materials.

A coffee pod typically contains about 5.7g of coffee, slightly less than the 7g used in a standard cup of filter coffee, which helps reduce the environmental impact of raw materials. Energy Use : While pod machines heat only the amount needed, they still consume more energy per cup than traditional brewing methods, such as French press or drip systems.

Home vs. Industrial Compostability

Most compostable pods, including those made from plant-based PLA, will not break down in backyard bins. They require sustained heat and controlled moisture, which industrial composting provides, whereas typical home piles can’t achieve.

Terms like bioplastic, biodegradable, and compostable are often confused, but they aren’t the same. Bioplastics aren’t always compostable, and true compostable plastics, such as PLA, require industrial conditions defined by the ASTM D6400 and EN 13432 standards in the U.S. and Europe, respectively, to break down. Misunderstanding these labels can lead to improper disposal and contaminate recycling or composting systems.

Industrial Composting facilities maintain optimal conditions for full pod breakdown. Pilot studies, including those conducted by the University of Tennessee, have shown that compostable pods break down entirely within 46 days in industrial facilities. These pilots help test the real-world viability of compostable packaging.

Yet, as of 2023, only about 200 industrial composting facilities in the U.S. accept compostable packaging, fewer than 15% of all composting sites nationwide.

Barriers to Better Composting

Many U.S. consumers are unsure whether coffee pods are recyclable or compostable, leading to confusion about proper disposal. Their confusion is compounded by infrastructure gaps in many regions, where industrial composting facilities are unavailable. Beneath these difficulties, the primary reason for recycling inconsistencies is the financial constraints on local governments, which struggle to fund effective composting and recycling systems.

Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) policies represent an emerging approch to recycling regulation that holds manufacturers accountable for their products and packaging throughout their lifecycle, from creation to disposal. EPR promises to reduce the financial burden of recycling on local governments and encourages manufacturers to use recyclable or compostable materials.

While there are no coffee-specific EPR laws, states like Washington and Maryland are pioneering EPR programs that will force the coffee pod industry to adopt sustainability. Initially, pod makers will be required by states to provide clear labeling and establish take-back systems for used pods. With EPR funding, we can improve composting and recycling infrastructure more generally.

Reducing Your Footprint: What Helps

Composting is more sustainable and more cost-effective. First, it reduces the volume required for landfills while significantly helping to reduce methane gas emissions, a potent greenhouse gas. Second, the process turns organic waste into nutrient-rich compost, which can be used to enhance soil health. This value-added product contributes greatly to sustainable farming, creating a closed-loop system where waste is recycled back into the land, enriching it for future growth.

A growing number of companies offer alternatives to aluminum and plastic coffee pods:

Woken Coffee : Home-compostable, Nespresso-com patible pods

321 Coffee : Distributed at Whole Foods, these Keurig- and Nespresso-compatible pods are compostable at home or an industrial facility

Tayst Coffee : These industrially compostable Keurig-compatible, plant-based pods are plastic-free

Pod & Parcel : Nespresso-compatible pods shipped from Australia.

To reduce your coffee pod waste, consider these solutions:

Reusable Pods : Refillable options eliminate waste and reduce emissions.

Innovative Materials : Choose certified compostable or recyclable pods, and ensure they’re disposed of properly.

Take-Back Programs : Support brands with mail-in programs for aluminum pods, including Nespresso (which requires purchasing pods directly from the company), or send your used pods to TerraCycle .

Advocate for EPR policies : Encourage your local representatives to adopt EPR laws.

Where to Compost Pods?

If you want to compost your coffee pods or organic waste, there are numerous options available. CompostNow serves cities like Atlanta, Asheville, Cincinnati, and Raleigh-Durham. Bootstrap Compost is available in Boston, Providence, and Worcester, while Compost Crew covers D.C., Maryland, and Virginia. If you live in other areas, find local options by checking directories, including Earth911’s Recycling Locator (add your ZIP Code to this search) or GreenPaper Products, which offers a state-by-state composting guide. The Institute for Local Self-Reliance also provides a map of community composting programs.

If you prefer home composting and the pods you have can break down at lower temperatures, vermicomposting is a great option for small spaces. Backyard bins also work well if you have the room.

Coffee pods offer convenience but at an environmental cost. Reducing their footprint requires better design, stronger infrastructure, and coordinated action. With support from producers, consumers, and policymakers, we can brew a more sustainable future.

About the Author

Fizza Nabeel is an experienced sustainability writer with nearly a decade of expertise in eco-friendly practices. She specializes in simplifying complex environmental topics into actionable insights. Fizza currently works with DRIDER ZERO 9 E SCOOTER, promoting sustainable transportation.
articles.reasoning: The article addresses the environmental impact of coffee pod waste and suggests ways to reduce it, which aligns with environmental progress and conservation efforts. This promotes awareness and encourages positive action towards sustainability.
articles.personality_title: Small changes to reduce your coffee pod waste
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Every year, more than 20 billion coffee pods are thrown away worldwide. That’s about 39,000 coffee pods made every minute! These pods, often made from plastic or aluminum, create a big problem because many end up in landfills and are hard to recycle properly.

**What happened**
Experts and environmental groups are raising awareness about the huge waste from coffee pods and sharing easy ways to cut down on it. For example, some suggest switching to reusable coffee pods, which you can fill with your own coffee grounds instead of tossing single-use ones. Others recommend choosing pods made from compostable materials that break down more easily in nature.

**Impact**
These small changes can make a big difference. Using reusable or compostable pods helps reduce the amount of trash that ends up in the landfill and lowers the need for new plastic production. This helps protect the environment and supports a more sustainable way of enjoying your daily coffee.

**What's next step**
The next step is for more coffee lovers and companies to adopt these greener options. Spreading the word about the benefits and making compostable or reusable pods more available can encourage more people to make the switch and reduce waste on a larger scale.

**One-sentence takeaway**
You can enjoy your coffee while helping the planet by choosing reusable or compostable coffee pods to cut down on waste.
articles.personality_title_fr: De petits gestes pour réduire vos déchets de dosettes de café
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Chaque année, plus de 20 milliards de dosettes de café sont jetées dans le monde. Cela représente environ 39 000 dosettes fabriquées chaque minute ! Ces dosettes, souvent en plastique ou aluminium, posent un gros problème car beaucoup finissent en décharge et sont difficiles à recycler correctement.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des experts et groupes environnementaux sensibilisent sur l’énorme quantité de déchets liés aux dosettes et partagent des solutions simples pour les réduire. Par exemple, certains recommandent d’utiliser des dosettes réutilisables que l’on remplit avec son propre café, au lieu de jeter des dosettes à usage unique. D’autres suggèrent de choisir des dosettes compostables qui se décomposent plus facilement dans la nature.

**Impact**
Ces petits gestes peuvent avoir un grand effet. Utiliser des dosettes réutilisables ou compostables aide à réduire les déchets en décharge et diminue la fabrication de plastique neuf. Cela protège l’environnement et encourage une manière plus durable de savourer son café.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
La prochaine étape est que plus d’amateurs de café et d’entreprises adoptent ces options écologiques. Diffuser l’information sur ces avantages et rendre les dosettes compostables ou réutilisables plus accessibles peut encourager plus de personnes à changer leurs habitudes et réduire les déchets à grande échelle.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Vous pouvez profiter de votre café tout en aidant la planète en choisissant des dosettes réutilisables ou compostables pour réduire les déchets.
articles.personality_title_es: Pequeños cambios para reducir tus residuos de cápsulas de café
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Cada año se desechan más de 20 mil millones de cápsulas de café en todo el mundo. ¡Eso es alrededor de 39,000 cápsulas producidas cada minuto! Estas cápsulas, a menudo hechas de plástico o aluminio, crean un gran problema porque muchas terminan en vertederos y son difíciles de reciclar adecuadamente.

**Qué pasó**
Expertos y grupos ambientales están aumentando la conciencia sobre la gran cantidad de desechos de cápsulas de café y compartiendo formas fáciles de reducirlos. Por ejemplo, algunos sugieren cambiar a cápsulas reutilizables, que puedes rellenar con tu propio café en lugar de desechar cápsulas de un solo uso. Otros recomiendan elegir cápsulas hechas de materiales compostables que se descomponen más fácilmente en la naturaleza.

**Impacto**
Estos pequeños cambios pueden hacer una gran diferencia. Usar cápsulas reutilizables o compostables ayuda a reducir la cantidad de basura que termina en vertederos y disminuye la necesidad de producir plástico nuevo. Esto protege el medio ambiente y apoya una forma más sostenible de disfrutar tu café diario.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente paso es que más amantes del café y empresas adopten estas opciones más ecológicas. Difundir la información sobre los beneficios y hacer que las cápsulas compostables o reutilizables estén más disponibles puede motivar a más personas a hacer el cambio y reducir los residuos a gran escala.

**Frase clave**
Puedes disfrutar tu café mientras ayudas al planeta eligiendo cápsulas reutilizables o compostables para reducir los desechos.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a cozy kitchen scene featuring colorful reusable coffee pods and compostable pods nestled in a small, thriving indoor garden of rich soil and sprouting plants, with gentle steam rising from a cup of fresh coffee beside a recycling bin and a compost bin, all rendered in soft, natural earth tones and subtle greens, symbolizing sustainable coffee habits and eco-friendly waste reduction.

articles.title: 3 Tips for Green Finger Painting Fun
articles.summary:
As a mother of two, I know first-hand that finger painting can be both a...
The post 3 Tips for Green Finger Painting Fun appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
As a mother of two, I know first-hand that finger painting can be both a ridiculously messy and a super fun activity for toddlers and babies as young as six months old. Painting helps develop healthy sensory skills by giving young children a tactile experience.

Unfortunately, many children will want to experience finger paint by putting it in their mouths and smearing it everywhere within reach. If you are at your wit’s end trying to find paint that poses no risk to your child or the environment, this article is for you. Here are a few simple tips and nontoxic finger paint recipes to help make finger painting a safe and green activity for your child.

Read Labels Even on Nontoxic Finger Paint

Although the label may state that the product is nontoxic, it is not necessarily edible and may contain harmful ingredients. Some children will have a reaction to ingesting paints, even if they don’t cause long-term consequences. If the label states that it is harmful if swallowed, don’t buy it. Find a safer alternative.

Reduce Waste with Reusable Canvases and Bottles

Finger paints are among the easiest arts and crafts for young children. All you need is the paint and a canvas — be it a plate, cookie sheet, egg carton, yogurt tub, newspaper or even a tabletop. Look in your kitchen cabinets or recycling bin for ideas on zero-waste art materials. Preschoolers or elementary-age children may even enjoy making and painting 3D sculptures with reusable materials.

Make Your Own Edible Paints

If you are going to be covering your kid’s hands with paint, you want it to be safe enough to ingest. How can you encourage artistic self-expression and protect your children from chemical exposures? Create your own finger paints from ingredients in your pantry, of course.

Homemade finger paints can be created with a variety of food ingredients. Happily, inexpensive kitchen staples such as flour, salt, and cornstarch can provide hours of creative fun. It depends on what you have on hand at the moment. Keep food allergies and sensitivities in mind, as anything your child cannot eat should not be used to create finger paints.

Put the paints in reusable condiment squeeze bottles for easy dispensing. If the paint comes out too thick, gradually add a bit of water until it is the right consistency. Avoid making paints that are so watery that they run. Add a teaspoon of sand if you want to add texture to your paints, and store extra paint in the refrigerator to extend its useful life.

While the recipes are edible, they won’t necessarily be tasty. But you’ll have peace of mind knowing that your kids aren’t ingesting harmful chemicals or toxins if they put their fingers in their mouth when you use these nontoxic fingerpaints:

This finger paint recipe combines sugar, salt, and cornstarch, along with water and food coloring.

Here’s a great paint recipe that uses rice flour and gives ideas on natural plant coloring from cabbage or beet juice.

Only have cornstarch, water, and food dyes on hand, or do you want to make something simple? This edible finger paint recipe is for you.

Now roll up your sleeves and get busy with some green finger painting fun!

Editor’s Note: Originally published in October 2014, this article was updated in July 2025.
articles.reasoning: The article promotes green finger painting, which suggests environmentally friendly art activities for children, encouraging creativity and eco-consciousness. This aligns with environmental progress and educational engagement.
articles.personality_title: 3 simple tips for eco-friendly finger painting fun with kids
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Finger painting is a favorite activity for toddlers and babies, helping them explore textures and colors. But many parents worry about messy paint getting everywhere or little ones putting paint in their mouths.

**What happened**
A helpful guide shared three easy tips for green finger painting, which means using eco-friendly, non-toxic paints that are safe for kids and kind to the environment. This way, children can enjoy finger painting without any worry about harmful chemicals.

**Impact**
These green finger painting tips encourage creativity while protecting children’s health and teaching them about caring for the planet. It transforms a fun activity into a safe, educational experience.

**What's next step**
Parents can try making their own natural paints at home using common kitchen ingredients like flour, water, and food coloring. This not only keeps it green but also saves money and involves kids in the process.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Eco-friendly finger painting is a simple, safe way to nurture creativity and environmental awareness in young children.
articles.personality_title_fr: 3 conseils simples pour s’amuser avec la peinture écologique au doigt
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La peinture au doigt est une activité préférée des tout-petits, qui leur permet d’explorer les textures et les couleurs. Mais beaucoup de parents craignent les dégâts ou que leurs enfants goûtent à la peinture.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Un guide utile a partagé trois conseils faciles pour peindre au doigt de façon écologique, en utilisant des peintures non toxiques, sûres pour les enfants et respectueuses de l’environnement. Ainsi, les enfants peuvent s’amuser sans risque.

**Impact**
Ces conseils encouragent la créativité tout en protégeant la santé des enfants et en leur apprenant à prendre soin de la planète. L’activité devient à la fois ludique et éducative.

**Prochaine étape**
Les parents peuvent fabriquer leurs propres peintures naturelles à la maison avec des ingrédients courants comme la farine, l’eau et du colorant alimentaire. C’est économique, écologique, et cela engage les enfants.

**En une phrase**
La peinture au doigt écologique est une façon simple et sûre de développer la créativité et la conscience environnementale des jeunes enfants.
articles.personality_title_es: 3 consejos simples para divertirse con pintura de dedos ecológica
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La pintura con los dedos es una actividad favorita para los niños pequeños que les ayuda a explorar texturas y colores. Pero muchos padres se preocupan por el desorden o que los niños se lleven pintura a la boca.

**Qué pasó**
Una guía útil compartió tres consejos fáciles para pintar con los dedos de manera ecológica, usando pinturas no tóxicas, seguras para los niños y respetuosas con el medio ambiente. Así, los niños pueden divertirse sin preocupaciones.

**Impacto**
Estos consejos fomentan la creatividad mientras protegen la salud de los niños y les enseñan a cuidar el planeta. La actividad se convierte en algo divertido y educativo.

**Próximo paso**
Los padres pueden hacer sus propias pinturas naturales en casa con ingredientes comunes como harina, agua y colorante alimentario. Esto es económico, ecológico e involucra a los niños.

**En una frase**
La pintura de dedos ecológica es una forma simple y segura de fomentar la creatividad y la conciencia ambiental en los niños pequeños.
articles.image_prompt: A cozy, softly lit kitchen scene featuring colorful jars of homemade edible finger paints made from natural ingredients like flour and beets on a wooden table, with playful baby handprints and toddler-sized paintbrushes on a reusable canvas made from recycled materials, all rendered in gentle, natural tones with a warm, inviting atmosphere.
